Blog Section

Tip Calculator

Posted by Jonathan on Jan 02 2024

The takeaway task for session 9. Intro to JS - Programming Concepts. This task introduces the use of JavaScript to add dynamic interactions with web pages. I initially created a Script tag into my index.html page and initiated variables to take the value of the bill via a prompt and calculate the value of the tip from a fixed percentage of 25% using the document.write method to output the total bill. I checked using the typeof operator that I was dealing with numbers at all times and utilised the toFixed method to round the output as per the task instructions. As I had a number of lines of code in my script tag, I moved the JavaScript to a separate file and linked to this from the html head. Unfortunately, I experienced problems with document.write in a separate JS file within VSCode, with the browser console throwing errors. I moved my code to CodePen and did not experience this issue there. I now made further changes to the code, changing the input method to a input field within the webpage with a submit button initiating a JS function to calculate the tip from the input bill value. Once working, I transferred the code back to VSCode and did not experience any further issues with document.write method, all seemed to be working as expected.

Intro to JS - Functions and Control Flow

Posted by Jonathan on Jan 10 2024

In this session learners were taught about how to write a function in Javascript. The learners also have to call the function to make it run. They were introduced to control flow and how to use logic inside of a function to return an output.

Task 1 - Write a function that outputs a sentence. Then invoke/use that function.
function sentence() { console.log('This is a sentence.') }
sentence();
Task 2 - Write a simple program to combine a first name and a last name inside a function. Then update the function to accept a first and last name as arguments.
function name(first, last) { console.log("Full Name: " + first + " " + last); }
name('Jim', 'Argument');
Task 3 - Add a return statement to your 'name' function. Use that function to set the value of a variable.
function name(first, last) { return "Full Name: " + first + " " + last; } let fullName = name('Jim', 'Return')
console.log(fullName);
Task 3 function as Arrow function
const name = (first, last) => "Full Name: " + first + " " + last;
console.log(name('Jim', 'Arrow'));
task 4.1 - Make a variable called "temperature". Write some code that tells you to put on a coat if it is less than 50.
let temperature = 49; if (temperature < 50) { console.log("Put on a coat") }
Task 4.2 - If it's less than 50 degrees, “wear a coat.” If it's less than 30 degrees, “wear a coat and a hat.” If it's less than 0 degrees, “stay inside.” Otherwise, “just pants and vest is fine.”
let temperature = 60; if (temperature < 0) { console.log("Stay inside.");
} else if (temperature < 30) { console.log("Wear a coat and a hat.");
} else if (temperature < 50) { console.log("Wear a coat.");
} else { console.log("Just pants and vest is fine.") }
Task 4.3 - Add a logical operator to your ‘Shall I wear a coat?’ program
let temperature = 25; let hat = true; if (temperature < 0) { console.log("Stay inside.");
} else if (temperature < 30 && hat) { console.log("Wear a coat and a hat.");
} else if (temperature < 50) { console.log("Wear a coat.");
} else { console.log("Just pants and vest is fine.") }

Practicals - Intro to JS - Functions and Control Flow - Tasks

Posted by Jonathan on Jan 17 2024

In this session learners completed practical tasks set to help them further understand the previous 2 sessions in 'Intro to JS - Programming Concept' and 'Intro to JS - Functions and Control Flow'.

Task 1 - Create a function that is able to return a percentage of a number. For example you want to know what 30% of 135 is.

  1. Create a function named percentageCalculator
  2. Add 2 arguments for “number” and “percentage”
  3. Do the maths required to work out a percentage with the arguments
  4. Return the result of the maths
  5. Console.log the returned value
function percentageCalculator (number, percentage) {
return number * percentage / 100;
}

console.log(percentageCalculator(135, 30));

/* Arrow function */
percentageCalculator = (number, percentage) => number * percentage / 100;

console.log(percentageCalculator(135, 30));

/* Using variables */
const number = 135
const percentage = 30

percentageCalculator = (number, percentage) => number * percentage / 100;

console.log(percentageCalculator(number, percentage));

/* Make dynamic by UI '+ ensures that string from UI is a number' */
const number = +prompt('What number')
const percentage = +prompt('what Percentage')

percentageCalculator = (number, percentage) => number * percentage / 100;

const result = percentageCalculator(number, percentage);

alert(`${percentage}% of ${number} is ${result}` )
Task 2 - Customers can order 3 types of drink in 3 sizes. Cola, Lemonade and Orangeade Small, Medium and Large The button they press have the values “cola”,”lemon”,”orange” Create a function that will return the message “You have ordered a {size} of {softDrinkLabel}

  1. Create a function named drinkOrder
  2. Add 2 arguments for “size” and “buttonName”
  3. Use a switch statement to determine where the functional code needs to be written
  4. Create a message in each case statement to be returned.
  5. Console.log the returned message.
  • Additional look at arrays - make dynamic
let buttonName = 'orange'
let size = 'Small'

function drinkOrder (buttonName, size) {
switch (buttonName) {
case 'cola':
return `You have ordered a ${size} of Cola`
case 'lemon':
return `You have ordered a ${size} of Lemonade`
case 'orange':
return `You have ordered a ${size} of Orangeade`
}
}
console.log(drinkOrder(buttonName, size))

/* Make dynamic by UI */
const arrSize = ["Small","Medium","Large"];
const arrButtonName = ["cola","lemon","orange"]

/* Ensure drink size entry capitalised */
function titleCase(str) {
var splitStr = str.toLowerCase().split(' ');
for (var i = 0; i < splitStr.length; i++) {
splitStr[i] = splitStr[i].charAt(0).toUpperCase() + splitStr[i].substring(1);
}
return splitStr.join(' ');
}

let buttonName
let size

/* Prompt for drink type until correct entry */
do{
/* Ensure buttonName is lowercase */
buttonName = prompt('What type of drink: cola, lemon, orange').toLowerCase()
} while (arrButtonName.indexOf(buttonName) === -1);

/* Prompt for drink size until correct entry */
do{
size = titleCase(prompt('What size of drink: Small, Medium and Large'))
} while (arrSize.indexOf(size) === -1);

function drinkOrder (size, buttonName) {
switch (buttonName) {
case 'cola':
return `You have ordered a ${size} of Cola`
case 'lemon':
return `You have ordered a ${size} of Lemonade`
case 'orange':
return `You have ordered a ${size} of Orangeade`
}
}
console.log(drinkOrder(size, buttonName))
Task 3 - We need to create a function capable of using the addition, subtraction, multiply, divider or modulus operator on 2 numbers provided.
let number1 = 7
let number2 = 5
let operator = '%'

function calculator (number1, number2, operator) {
switch (operator) {
case '+':
return number1 + number2
// break; don't need as return breaks out
case '-':
return number1 - number2
case '*':
return number1 * number2
case '/':
return number1 / number2
case '%':
return number1 % number2
}
}

let value = calculator(number1, number2, operator)

console.log(`${number1} ${operator} ${number2} = ${value}`)

/* Make dynamic by UI */
/* Extra work - Think how you could add validation to this script */
const arrOperator = ["+","-","*","/","%"];

/* Prompt for input until a number is entered */
function validate (argument) {
let number
do{
number = Number(prompt(`Enter ${argument}`))
} while (!(!Number.isNaN(number)));
return number
}

let number1 = validate("number1")
let operator

/* Prompt for input until a correct operator is entered */
do{
operator = prompt('Enter operator: +, -, *, /, %')
} while (arrOperator.indexOf(operator) === -1);

let number2 = validate("number2")

function calculator (number1, number2, operator) {
switch (operator) {
case '+':
return number1 + number2
// break; don't need as return breaks out
case '-':
return number1 - number2
case '*':
return number1 * number2
case '/':
return number1 / number2
case '%':
return number1 % number2
}
}

let value = calculator(number1, number2, operator)

console.log(`${number1} ${operator} ${number2} = ${value}`)
